factoid: The tall, round-faced peasant remarked, 'Yes, they worked all day and didn’t play!'.

Rostóv was unwilling to obtrude himself on Princess Mary.
Rostóv did not go back to the house.
Rostóv remained in the village awaiting Princess Mary's departure.
Princess Mary's carriage drove out of the house.
Rostóv mounted the carriage and accompanied Princess Mary eight miles from Boguchárovo to the road occupied by our troops.
At the inn at Yankóvo, Rostóv respectfully took leave of Princess Mary.
At the inn at Yankóvo, Rostóv permitted himself to kiss Princess Mary's hand for the first time.
Rostóv blushingly replied, 'How can you speak so!' to Princess Mary's expressions of gratitude for her deliverance.
Princess Mary expressed gratitude for her deliverance.
Rostóv said, 'Any police officer would have done as much!'.
Rostóv said, 'If we had had only peasants to fight, we should not have let the enemy come so far.'.
Rostóv said, 'I am only happy to have had the opportunity of making your acquaintance.'.
Rostóv said, 'Good‑by, Princess.'.
Rostóv said, 'I wish you happiness and consolation and hope to meet you again in happier circumstances.'.
Rostóv said, 'If you don’t want to make me blush, please don’t thank me!'.
Princess Mary thanked Rostóv with the whole expression of her face, radiant with gratitude and tenderness.
Princess Mary could not believe that there was nothing to thank Rostóv for.
Princess Mary believed that if Rostóv had not been there she would have perished at the hands of the mutineers and of the French.
Princess Mary believed that Rostóv had exposed himself to terrible and obvious danger to save her.
Princess Mary believed that Rostóv was a man of lofty and noble soul, able to understand her position and her sorrow.
Princess Mary's kind, honest eyes had tears rising when she began to cry as she spoke of her loss.
The tears in Princess Mary's eyes remained in her memory.
After taking leave of Rostóv and remaining alone, Princess Mary felt her eyes filling with tears.
Princess Mary wondered if she loved Rostóv.
Dunyásha accompanied Princess Mary on the rest of the way to Moscow in the carriage.
Dunyásha more than once noticed that Princess Mary leaned out of the carriage window and smiled at something with an expression of mingled joy and sorrow.
Princess Mary thought, 'Well, supposing I do love him?'.
Princess Mary was ashamed of acknowledging to herself that she had fallen in love with a man who would perhaps never love her.
Princess Mary comforted herself with the thought that no one would ever know it.

Princess Mary comforted herself with the thought that she would not be to blame if she continued to love the man with whom she had fallen in love for the first and last time in her life without ever speaking of it to anyone.
When Princess Mary recalled Rostóv's looks, his sympathy, and his words, happiness did not appear impossible to her.
Dunyásha noticed Princess Mary smiling as she looked out of the carriage window at those moments.
Princess Mary thought, 'Was it not fate that brought him to Boguchárovo, and at that very moment?'.
Princess Mary thought, 'And that caused his sister to refuse my brother?'.
Princess Mary saw the hand of Providence in all this.
The impression Princess Mary made on Rostóv was very agreeable.
Remembering Princess Mary gave Rostóv pleasure.
Rostóv grew angry when his comrades, hearing of his adventure at Boguchárovo, rallied him on having gone to look for hay and having picked up one of the wealthiest heiresses in Russia.
Rostóv grew angry because the idea of marrying Princess Mary, who was attractive to him and had an enormous fortune, had against his will more than once entered his head.
Rostóv believed that by marrying Princess Mary he would make the countess his mother happy.
Rostóv believed that by marrying Princess Mary he would be able to put his father's affairs in order.
Rostóv believed that by marrying Princess Mary he would ensure Princess Mary's happiness.
